introduction.p: We can always check a solution to an equation by verifying that it makes the equation true.

statement.p: Verify that x=-5 is a solution of the equation ~~x^2+2x-15=0

solution.p: We show that substituting -5 for x makes the equation true. When we substitute a negative number for a variable, we should enclose the number in parentheses. \begin{aligned}[t] x^2+2x-15 \amp = (\alert{-5})^2+2(\alert{-5})-15\\ \amp = 25-10-15=0 \end{aligned} Because the expression does equal 0, we see that x=-5 is a solution.

statement.p: Verify that x=-3 is not a solution of the equation ~~\sqrt{2x+10}-3x=8

solution.p: We show that substituting -3 for x does not make the equation true. \begin{aligned}[t] \sqrt{2x+10}-3x \amp = \sqrt{2(\alert{-3})+10}-3(\alert{-3})\\ \amp = \sqrt{4}+9=2+9=11 \not= 8 \end{aligned} The left side of the equation does not equal 8 when x=-3, so x=-3 is not a solution.

subsection.title: 3. Solve an equation in two variables

introduction.p: A solution of an equation in two variables x and y is written as an ordered pair, (x,y). For example, the solution (-2,5) means that x=-2 and y=5.

statement.p: Is (-3,2) a solution of the equation ~~x^2+4y^2=25 ?

solution.p: We substitute x=\alert{-3} and y=\alert{2} into the equation. (\alert{-3})^2+4(\alert{2})^2=9+4(4)=9+16=25 The ordered pair (-3,2) satisfies the equation, so it is a solution.

sidebyside.p:
Which of the following ordered pairs are solutions of the equation whose graph is shown?
(-3,-2)
(-5,0)
(1,-4)
(-1,-6)

solution.p: The graph of an equation is just a picture of its solutions, so points that lie on the graph are solutions of the equation.
The points (-3,-2) and (-1,-6) lie on the graph, so they represent solutions of the equation. The points (-5,0) and (1,-4) do not lie on the graph, so they are not solutions of the equation.
